summary_points: 1. Verisk Analytics sold its AER business in December 2024, resulting in a $12.1 million loss.
2. Accounts receivable increased by 30% year-over-year to $434.4 million in 2024, while outstanding senior notes increased by $200 million to $3,050 million.
3.  As of December 31, 2024, Verisk had $591.5 million remaining in its share repurchase program.
1. Verisk Analytics, Inc. reported consolidated revenues of $2,882 million for the full year 2024, a 7.5% increase compared to 2023.
2.  For the fourth quarter of 2024, diluted adjusted earnings per share from continuing operations were $1.61, a 15.0% increase compared to the same period in 2023.
3. Verisk provides financial guidance for fiscal year 2025, projecting revenue between $3,030 million and $3,080 million and diluted adjusted EPS between $6.80 and $7.10.

1. NRG Energy, Inc. reported GAAP Net Income of $1.1 billion for the full year 2024, a significant increase from a loss of $(202) million in 2023, primarily due to unrealized mark-to-market gains on economic hedges in 2024.
2.  As of February 20, 2025, NRG had completed $174 million of its planned $1.3 billion share repurchase for 2025.
3.  NRG has a Project Development Agreement with GE Vernova and Kiewit to develop up to 5.4 GW of new gas-fired generation, with the first projects expected to commence operations by the end of 2029.

1. 3M reiterated its 2025 guidance and provided an adjusted outlook for 2026 and 2027, projecting organic sales growth outperforming macroeconomic trends, an operating margin of approximately 25% by 2027, high-single-digit EPS growth annually, and over 100% free cash flow conversion.
2.  In 2024, 3M made net pre-tax cash payments of approximately $4.5 billion related to significant litigation costs and approximately $245 million in divestiture costs.
3.  3M plans to exit manufactured PFAS products by the end of 2025, with the associated impact on financial results presented as special items in its non-GAAP reporting.
1. General Motors increased its share repurchase program by $6.3 billion on February 24, 2025, leaving $4.3 billion remaining.
2.  General Motors reduced its outstanding shares by approximately 110 million (10.4%) between December 31, 2023 and December 31, 2024.
3.  The company will increase its quarterly dividend by $0.03 per share starting in April 2025.
1. Dayforce, Inc. announced an efficiency plan on February 26, 2025, which includes a 5% reduction in its global workforce and is expected to be substantially completed by March 31, 2025.
2.  The plan is projected to generate approximately $65 million in pre-tax cost savings in fiscal year 2025 and $80 million on an annualized run-rate basis.

3. The company anticipates incurring total non-recurring restructuring charges of approximately $18 million to $21 million pre-tax for severance and related costs, plus $6 million to $8 million in non-cash charges for stock-based compensation, in the first quarter of 2025.
1. As of February 25, 2025, News Corporation had repurchased approximately US$641,103,176.80 worth of Class A and Class B shares under its US$1 billion stock repurchase program.
2. On February 25, 2025, 21,067,284 Class A shares and 10,393,900 Class B shares were repurchased, totaling US$640,873,825.22.
3. News Corporation's stock repurchase program, which aims to enhance shareholder value, is ongoing and subject to market conditions and other factors.
1. News Corp repurchased approximately US$641,103,176.80 worth of Class A and Class B shares as of February 25, 2025, under a US$1 billion stock repurchase program.

2. On February 25, 2025,  21,067,284 Class A shares and 10,393,900 Class B shares were repurchased, at a highest price of US$30.69 and US$35.25 respectively, and a lowest price of US$14.88 and US$15.17 respectively.
3. News Corp's stock repurchase program intends to continue repurchasing shares from time to time, subject to market conditions and other factors.
1. Coterra Energy Inc. completed two significant acquisitions totaling $4 billion in January 2025, resulting in a projected 28% increase in their 2025 capital program.
2.  Coterra's net income decreased by $504 million year-over-year in 2024, reaching $1.1 billion.
3. A stockholder derivative lawsuit against Coterra remains under appeal as of February 3, 2025.
1. Coterra Energy Inc. significantly increased its long-term debt by $1.95 billion in 2024, reaching $3.535 billion by December 31, 2024.
2.  Net income fell by $504 million year-over-year (2024 vs 2023), primarily due to lower natural gas prices and production.
3. Coterra's 2025 capital expenditure program is projected to be between $2.1 billion and $2.4 billion, a 28% increase at the midpoint compared to 2024, primarily driven by recent acquisitions.
1. Walgreens Boots Alliance, Inc. settled a commercial arbitration award with Everly Health Solutions on February 24, 2025, agreeing to pay $595 million to resolve all claims.

2.  The settlement amount of $595 million is significantly lower than the original arbitration award of $988 million (including pre-award interest), but higher than the contractual damage cap of $79 million.
3. The settlement avoids further accrual of post-award interest and the costs and uncertainty of continued litigation.
1. Walgreens Boots Alliance settled a commercial arbitration award with Everly Health Solutions for $595 million on February 24, 2025,  avoiding further litigation costs and interest accrual.
2.  The settlement amount of $595 million is significantly less than the original arbitration award of $988 million but more than the contractually capped amount of $79 million.
3. The settlement agreement, while avoiding further legal costs and uncertainties, does not include any admission of wrongdoing or liability by Walgreens Boots Alliance.
1. Teradyne, Inc. announced a Financial Analyst Day to be held on March 11, 2025, at its headquarters.
2.  The filing is an 8-K report, indicating other events occurred on February 25, 2025.
3. The Financial Analyst Day will feature presentations on Teradyne's strategic imperatives, operating and growth strategy, and business outlook.
1. Williams Companies' net income decreased significantly year-over-year, falling from $3,179 million in 2023 to $2,222 million in 2024.
2.  In 2025, Williams anticipates fulfilling $4,132 million in performance obligations from customer contracts.
3. Transco received an adverse $110 million judgment in February 2025, although they have appealed and expect partial recovery.
